metadata.case_name: Appellant (Indian National Congress nominee) v. Respondent No. 1 (Returned Candidate)

facts.text: Election from 168-Katoria Bihar Legislative Assembly Constituency took place in March, 1972. The poll was held on March 11, 1972 and the votes were counted on March 12, 1972.

Respondent No. 1, an independent candidate, was declared elected having secured 16649 votes as against 16074 polled by the appellant, a nominee of Indian National Congress. Respondents 2 to 4 secured 2347, 8001, 1542 votes respectively. Votes rejected as invalid: 1219.

On April 14, 1972, the appellant filed an election petition under the Representation of the People Act, 1951 challenging the election of the returned candidate on the ground that several irregularities and illegalities were committed in the counting of votes.

The petition was resisted by the returned candidate. The High Court framed issues, recorded evidence, held allegations not substantiated, declined recount and dismissed the petition on 25th September, 1973.
Four unauthorised persons, viz., Ajudhya Prasad Singh, Q. M. Zaman, Parvez Ahmed and Radhey Sham Sah were allowed to work as Counting Supervisors at tables 4, 5, 7 and 9.

In the first round of counting at table No. 4 in the box relating to polling station No. 74, Madhopur U.P. School, 50 unsigned ballot papers were found in excess of those actually polled. Assistant Returning Officer opened the packet of unused ballot papers in violation of Rule 93(1).
Detailed result-sheet prepared tablewise suppressed to prevent detection of mistakes.
About 600-700 uncounted ballot papers in bundles kept below Assistant Returning Officer's table. In final round, despite protest, 600 votes counted twice in favour of Respondent No. 1.
At end of third round, appellant leading by 2205 votes, but shown losing by 575 votes though only 3800 ballot papers left.
List Ex. 6 from District Election Officer does not mention the four persons as Counting Supervisors. Check Memos Ex. C/3, C/4, C/6, C/8 show they supervised.
Returning Officer maintained a waiting list of reserve officers for Counting Supervisors.

Part I of Ex. 4 (Ballot Paper Account for PS 74): unused 397, issued 323. Part II: found 373, discrepancy 'Found fifty excess including one ballot paper unsigned'. Packet opened, found actually 347 unused.
Final result-sheet Ex. 7 shows at end of third round, appellant leading by 424 votes only.
Petitioner's notes Ex. 2 series claimed 2205 lead after third round, but held self-serving and unreliable.

legal_issues.text: Whether order for inspection and recount of ballot papers should be made.
Whether four unauthorised persons acted as Counting Supervisors vitiating counting.
Whether opening packet of unused ballot papers violated Rule 93(1) vitiating counting.
Whether suppression of detailed result-sheet prevented detection of manipulations.
Whether 600-700 uncounted ballot papers were mixed and counted twice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Four unauthorised persons allowed as Counting Supervisors at tables 4,5,7,9 in breach of rules, vitiating counting.
50 unsigned ballot papers in excess at table 4 for PS 74; Assistant Returning Officer opened packet violating Rule 93(1).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 93(1) of Conduct of Election Rules

petitioner_arguments.text: 600 votes counted twice for Respondent No.1; 600-700 uncounted papers under table mixed in.
Appellant leading by 2205 after third round, but lost by 575 though only 3800 left.

respondent_arguments.text: Allegations of irregularities not substantiated; no violation shown.
Four persons were Government officials from reserve waiting list appointed by Returning Officer.

court_reasoning.text: Order for recount not as matter of course; secrecy of ballot; elaborate procedure with safeguards. Guidelines: adequate statement of material facts; prima facie established by evidence; imperatively necessary.
No allegation of unauthorised persons in petition; raised belatedly. Names not in Ex.6 but probable from reserve list; all Govt officials; presumption rite et acte.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No violation of Rule 53 or other provision.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 93(1) applies to post-election custody. Returning Officer competent to open and inspect during counting per Rules 56, 38(1). Handbook Instruction 23 confirms post-election.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act was necessary for duty under Rules.

court_reasoning.text: Detailed sheet not statutory; convenience only. Figures verifiable from Check Memos; no discrepancy shown.
Allegation changed over time; Ex.3 alleged double counting, untenable as total correct. Ex.7 shows lead 424 only; petitioner's notes unreliable.

holdings.text: Court would be justified in ordering recount only where: 1. adequate statement of material facts; 2. prima facie established by evidence; 3. imperatively necessary.
No violation by unauthorised supervisors; from reserve list.
Rule 93(1) post-election; opening packet lawful during counting.
Absence of detailed sheet immaterial; verifiable from Check Memos.
No evidence of double counting or uncounted papers mixed.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Election Rules, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulate counting, custody of papers, inspection; Rule 93 post-election custody

outcome.summary: The appeal against dismissal of election petition by Patna High Court is dismissed. No irregularities or illegalities established warranting recount. Appellant unable to make out case.
outcome.costs: Appellant shall pay the costs of Respondent No. 1

key_quotes.text: The Court would be justified in ordering a recount of the ballot papers, only where 1 the election-petition contains an adequate statement of all the material facts... 2. prima facie established... 3. imperatively necessary.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Rule 93(1) ... the custody ... is a post-election custody.
key_quotes.speaker: court
